ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: I learned so much about trees!
Not much knowledge was gained as each topic was very lightly touched upon and nothing was elaborated upon.
not tree identification. A whole lot about xylem and phloem, and I'm not happy about it.
I learned about tree biology. Not as much about tree identification as I would have liked. Idk, I feel like trees are much much cooler than this course.
I learned to appreciate nature more and I am now a lot more aware of different kinds of trees and how they contribute to our environment.
You learn the basics about tree biology and the impact of trees on the environment

I learned about the biology of trees, how they co-exist, how they support each other, who their enemies are (humans, It's definitely us). philosophically I think how trees operate can give insight on how humans should go about shaping their own lives, but of course we're not here for that.

Taking my senior week trip with friends after this course, was telling them all that I learned about trees with them, and they said wow you really learned a lot about trees didn't you and they are right!! Clear expectations, engaging lectures, good class setup makes this an excellent science course (for both science and non science majors)
A better knowledge of trees and plant physiology, as well as the cultural and economic value of trees.

Greatly enjoyed learning about tree physiology, how trees function within ecosystems, and the role of trees in everyday life! Learned how to critically think about scientific material and make interdisciplinary connections. I have such an enriched perspective on trees as I walk around campus now--whether determining the species, contemplating how they move gallons of water each day, or how old a certain tree is, I'm excited to apply the knowledge learned in this class to daily experiences.

I learned about the physiology of the tree (and plants generally), and how trees interact with the environment around them. I also learned how trees have impacted our culture through being used for making instruments and furniture, and how their physiology lends themselves to being a good building material.

I gained a nuanced understanding of trees. I learned about the complex systems that these organisms employ to transport water and nutrients, the threat of invasive species on trees, the role of trees in climate change, the process of photosynthesis, how forests change over time, as well as how to classify and measure trees, among many other things. I feel that I now have a broad understanding of how these organisms function and I've come to realize that there is so much more to trees that what meets the eye.

I learned a lot more about the ecological world around us--factors that influence the lifecycle and well-being of the plant world around us, in addition to the role we can play to better care for it. :)
A great overview of knowledge on trees, plants, and the environment!
I learned about trees; how water gets into them, how nutrients get through the tree and a tree's uses to man.

I learned a lot about the biology of trees and their place in the ecosystem (how photosynthesis works, how plants acquire nutrients/water, their interactions with underground mycorrhizal networks--the wood wide web [that's what scientist call them, no joke], how and why people use them for furniture/instruments among other things, their role with regard to climate change, and how invasive species are effecting them).
I learned about many different aspects of trees and plants - how they interact with their environment, their anatomy, their evolution, and also about their uses in furniture and musical instruments.
A thorough understanding of plant physiology. How trees interact, add to and defend themselves from their environment.
A new understanding of Trees. I appreciate the natural world around me so much more.
I learned a lot from this course.
The basics of tree anatomy.
I learned about tree anatomy

I learned a lot of facts about how trees work, though I didn't learn a lot about identifying them, which is what most people ask me about. Because of the structure of the course, you retain a surprising amount of details about the different aspects of trees and how they affect the world and climate change.
I learned about the evolutionary history, ecological function, and socio-cultural uses of trees.

I learned a lot about environmental biological pretty broadly. I expected to learn a lot about tree identification, but the course material is more on trees sustain themselves and interact with other processes, like climate change.
Contrary to misconceptions about this course - I actually learned a lot about trees, plants in general, the environment, and the biological networks within.

I learned about the necessary environmental conditions for trees to grow, how trees obtain nutrients and water, how trees compete, and how trees affect our environment. I learned more about the physical and biological characteristics of trees (down to a cellular scale) than I will ever need to know.
N/A

I learned a lot about the physiology of trees and the ways trees function within the global ecosystem and to counteract climate change, as well as the various uses for different types of trees and the greatest threats they face in nature.

I learned more than I ever would have imagined in this course. The material ranged for the mechanical/biological mechanisms of trees and other vascular plants to the evolution of land usage in New England. Overall, there was a wide breadth of information covered
Really developed an interesting understanding of tree anatomy and how it relates to the environment and some of the growing concerns of the earth around us.
Hoped to learn the underlying connections between different corporate and social groupings

I actually did learn a lot about trees. I feel like I understand their place in the ecosystem more and that I understand a lot about the material makeup of trees and how they have been used throughout human history. I found the history of the New England forests especially interesting.
I learned a lot about tree anatomy
Learned a lot about biology and the miraculous beings that are trees! You also learn how to measure a tree and how to kind of start thinking about identifying them.

I learned so so SO much about trees, including the uses of different woods with their respective physical properties, the biophysical component of tree metabolism, and their impacts on the environment.
Field work and actual material...very interesting combination...I look at the world in an entirely new light now that I understand so much more about the processes behind plants' and our own lives.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: This course is accessible to non-science majors but also interesting to someone like me who has taken three years of upper level biology and chemistry.
Strengths include a science credit. Weaknesses include the disorganization amount the professors and TAs, random grading, constant schedule changes, and poor lecture slides.
The course tries to do a bit too much and is a bit disorganized. Sometimes the lectures were a bit hard to follow and boring.

Large lecture, with a lot of students who didn't come. I thought the tests/grading were a little too hard, but the final wasn't bad at all. You don't really need to do any of the readings, which is nice, and all the slides are online, which makes studying pretty straight-forward. The TFs are pretty good, and sometimes you get to walk around and look at trees, which is definitely the highlight.
Section was pretty useless, but the professor is extremely engaging and the slides he uses are phenomenal.
The Pallardy reading was convoluted. I couldn't understand it until after lecture, maybe. Poorly written and not suitable for people who know nothing about biology.

strengths: professor broderson is great. Lecture is not always necessary to attend but when you do, you will enjoy listening to him talk about trees. I definitely left the course feeling I leaned at from him weaknesses: textbook was useless and it should be made clear that the text book is only a supplement to the lectures if you desire to learn more. Also, some of the homework assignments were unnecessarily tedious, such as the ones with the foldscopes which were an absolutely disaster to use. Lastly, I wished there was a bit more on actual tree identification on the course. If you want to take this course to learn how to identify many trees, then do not take it. You will only learn the basic ones.
I think that including how wood types influence instruments and furniture are interesting, but more as side knowledge, as less as course material that is on the exam.

STRENGTHS - very interesting information, cool class trips, cool assignments WEAKNESSES - isn't thorough in explaining things for people who do not know about biology/tree biology, terms would be introduced without being defined and those terms would be important to actually understanding the material, slides could be better and better labeled or explained because people do miss class for good reasons and looking at 30 slides of random graphs will not help them. Readings are trash; they also speak to people who know what the deal is about trees.
1. Reading list could be much improved to something more readable and testable 2. Be a little more organized on quiz dates and assignment due dates
Overall this was an amazing course. I would have liked more outdoor field trips, and I would preferred to have learned more about wood.

Strengths: Professor Brodersen's engaging lecture style; the TAs' enthusiasm; the content Weaknesses: some of the assignments felt a little superfluous; lack of interest from some students; the professor occasionally expected too much of a bio background

I loved the first half of the course when we were learning the physiology of the tree. I'm not that interested in biology, but it was interesting to understand the mechanics of how a tree functions. The second half of the course felt directionless though; we jumped from discrete topics that had something to do with trees. The coverage of each topic felt cursory though, and so I rarely felt engaged in what we were learning.

This course was very difficult for a non-science student; it touches on a wide variety of concepts but never really goes in depth. As a result, without a background, it is difficult to put two and two together in many situations where additional detail is needed. This course would greatly benefit from either being about tree anatomy or the use for trees, rather than both. In its current form it felt very rushed and was less informative as a result.
Some of the content was pretty bland during lecture

One of the strengths of this course was the lecture. I found the lecture to be very fascinating; Craig makes it pretty engaging while also being informative. Also, the discussion section was a good addition because it sort of reinforced the material from lecture and gave an avenue to delve into the curriculum in more depth; also the "field trips" that the discussion section went on were really nice. When it comes to weaknesses, I found myself not really doing the readings because I soon realized that they weren't really required for the curriculum. As much as I liked the book Life of a Leaf, I think it would be more useful to either have the readings be necessary (i.e. have quizzes on the readings) or just abandon the book altogether. Other than that, I think that this was a great class and can't really think of any further weaknesses!
Strengths: Professor Broderson is a great lecturer, really cares about and loves the material. Weaknesses: textbooks were not related to the course and did not really help.
I think the course was great in that the lectures were very much in sync with the exams and quizzes which made them great tools for later reference!

Strengths: quizzes were a great opportunity to show what you know, assignments were fun and helped me remember concepts, section was helpful, exams were fair Weaknesses: lecture was WAY to long, should be 50mins instead of 70 and I felt like we only need to know 40% of what is taught in lecture. I had trouble paying attention after 30-40 mins

The field trips are a bit useless, but are fun and interesting. The homework and quizzes aren't overly challenging and help drive home important concepts. Lecture is usually interesting, but the trek up science hill is tough sometimes. Though I really enjoyed getting to know my TF, section wasn't overly helpful. We didn't do much reading to really necessitate having a section to discuss things.

The strength of this course was in its interactiveness, especially through some of the assignments (such as finding the tallest/oldest trees on campus) and the discussion sections. I would have liked this class to be more interactive, with more trips outside of the classroom to learn, interact with, and talk about trees.

We could do more with the life of a leaf book, after the first couple of weeks in section, we didn't talk about it again. There was also way too much assigned reading that you really didn't have to do. I would suggest picking less so that the students can realistically do it, and then engaging with it more. Section was sometimes fun and sometimes super irrelevant. TAs like Laura make it a much stronger course because of their enthusiasm and insane amount of knowledge. The assignments and quizzes were good, but Craig strayed from the syllabus immediately and never got back onto one, which made the work impossible to follow and keep up with. It should definitely be re-organized. And Craig is a wonderful lecturer, but you can only hear him if you sit in the first two rows. He's mic'ed already, but PLEASE Craig, PLEASE speak up. He trails off every sentence and you don't catch the tail-end.
It was very organized and the professor was a very engaging lecturer.

Strengths. - Professor Brodersen and the TA's were phenomenal. - Interactive sections. the tours and practicals were a lot of fun and super helpful. Weaknesses. -The textbook acts more as a literature review. A textbook with a more focussed attention to explanation would be better suited for this class. For instance, thoughts in the text are continuously punctuated with references to other scientific works which can be distracting. I often studied with Taiz and Zeiger which I think would be a better fit for this class (Prof. Brodersen sometimes drew content from this very book) -A consistent timeline for assignments should be created and followed. At times assignments were created and announced only a few days before they were due. - Professor Brodersen puts a lot of thought into his slides, but they can be difficult to review before an exam.
Amazing TFs and fair exams. Weaknesses were some unnecessary field trips.
I think that the course was very interesting overall but it spread itself somewhat thin so not all of the topics got as in depth as they deserve.
I think that the course should be more applicable to the environment and appeal to non-stem majors.
I thought the lectures were interesting, but sometimes the tangents were boring. The information could have been given more succinctly.
Not many weaknesses, the course offers a great in-depth and varied look into the material. The course was well organized and assignments were all transparent and fair.

There was (though I think they tried to fix this) a huge gap in what we were expected to know in section/quizzes/homework and what we actually had to know for the exam. This made the class and the grading system really difficult to grasp because we were harshly graded on midterms and not on anything else. The multiple choice questions were kinda weird. Craig said he wrote tests by looking at the lectures and writing questions based on the slides, but it definitely didn't seem that way for some of the multiple choice on the exam. Section was also kinda weird because (even though I loved my TA) no section was alike, and we never knew what to expect, which made it hard to learn and relate section material with what we learned in lecture. The TAs are really great and so helpful in office hours and review sessions, so that out of class time was really essential to my understanding of the material. I think it would be great if lectures were posted ahead of time so we could look through the slides and know what information we had to look out for or had questions about.

This course needs to cast its net pretty broadly, because it has students of all skill/interest/engagement levels. It has to be accessible without completely sacrificing intellectual rigor; it has to teach important ecological principles without losing the interest of people who don't much care about ecology. I think it makes the right compromises.

The course is organized well and students are evaluated in a variety of ways (quizzes, assignments, exams), which is nice. The lectures are generally interesting and easy to follow. The furniture study visit is a highlight. Weaknesses of the course: I think the instrument study visit felt disorganized. I also wish we learned more about climate change and less about the commercial uses of wood. Also, some of my classmates in other sections and I noticed that our exams were graded slightly differently (some people lost points on things that others didnt), so it might be helpful to create a more decisive rubric in future semesters.
Strengths: Got to go outside often. Exceptional TF's. Weaknesses: Too long of lectures.

Strengths: some of the topics are interesting and the content is approachable in lecture Weaknesses: lectures are sometimes boring, sections are not helpful, the grading is extremely and unnecessarily harsh, there is a huge difference between the lecture (and how professor Brodersen portrays the course to students) and the TAs' standards for the students when they grade texts The course is not a gut. Seems easy and interesting, but grading is absurd.

The class should be 50 minutes rather than an hour and 15 minutes. I definitely think there was a lot of excessive and insignificant material covered that, if removed, would make a 50 minute class very doable.

Craig is an awesome lecturer and I loved this class. Sometimes the lectures can certainly drag, and the tests involved, especially at first, a lot of regurgitation, though the final really highlighted conceptual understanding, which I appreciated. Some of the homework felt like busywork. Maybe would be better as a 50 minute class.
strengths: great professor, really interesting content, nice and knowledgeable TAs can't think of weaknesses it was overall just a really good course.

I loved the hands-on activities in section and the assignments that required us to go out and find certain things, which helped me engage in the class material. Our section field trips were a particular favorite of mine.
Really enjoyed section, always seemed to be interesting. Lecture could sometimes be tough to sit through, and I feel like my engagement would have been higher had the class been an hour.
Well formatted exams. Good TFs

I thought the online quizzes were a good assessment. Most of the section assignments were good, though I found the Fibonacci sequence assignment a little bit unnecessary (though I think this is something that could be fixed by doing it a different way rather than eliminating it. I liked having learned about this and seen it in real life once we started learning about auxin). The lectures were interesting and the TFs great.
The homework assignments took too much time for the small number of points they counted for.

Strengths are that the lectures and assignments are really fun. The first test was very hard but they feel really fair if you study for them. For me (very little background in science) this class was NOT a gut, but it was challenging in a fun and fair way. Professor Brodersen is so cool.

It is a super interesting course (though I am personally biased because I love tress.) However it does tend to move in fits of difficulty- some classes I was writing ridiculously fast and absorbing lots of material, and others went at a much slower pace. Obviously some themes are more difficult or more information-heavy than others, but I still think the material could be divided more evenly.

I absolutely loved my discussion section and my TA. She really contributed to my success in this class. I loved how discussion sections were not boring, but in fact, eye-opening! The weakness, however, would be the lectures, which were not as engaging as I hoped it would be.

strengths - cool field trips, section is very helpful, material is taught in cool and clear topics/lessons weaknesses - class was too long and hard to stay focused, so I'd recommend shortening if possible, also exams seemed way to detailed and picky in grading...I understood so much of the broader topics and attended every lecture but 1, and studied the details, but I felt the exams were designed for people who simply memorized slide/textbook info

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: I would recommend this course to anyone interested in learning about an integral part of our environment
Definitely- if you need a science credit but hate science, this is a great one to choose.
No as I did not find it interesting or organized well to facilitate learning.
I would not recommend this course to a student for a science credit. Definitely better science courses out there!
I would recommend this course if the description sounds interesting to you. Additionally, if you have any interest in trees I recommend this course.

This class is crazy boring. If like me you desperately needed this science credit, it is okay. The University needs to do more to provide science credits for non-STEM people. The class isn't too hard, but it's not intuitive, so you really need to study a lot. Also the sections feel like being a kindergartner - including looking at musical instruments and tracing and cutting leaves. But the exams actually require work to do well on. Everything seems upside down in this class.

**PLEASE READ THIS REVIEW: Listen, I walked into this class hoping it would be very focused on tree identification and a chill science credit. As a non-STEM person, I was really hoping it would be a fun class in which I could learn some fun tree facts, do some worksheets, and not have to study for examinations (just being honest). This was not my experience. Trees is NOT a gut. While there is definitely not a big workload, the exams are not easy. I attended every lecture and discussion section throughout the semester and thought that because this class was advertised as a gut, that just going to lecture and section would be enough. I was dead wrong. I think this class is super chill for STEM people, but if youre literally anything else (even if youre a FOOT leader/Yale Outdoors person), I really doubt youll find this class interesting. There is a very small emphasis on topics that are relevant to non-STEM people (one lecture has a section on accessible climate change information, but thats it). Because lecture was really not great, it made it difficult to find the material interesting and enjoy studying for exams. Im going to be honest: Im a vegetarian; Im a FOOT leader; I self-identify as a tree-hugger. But, after taking this class, I kind of despise trees. Im going to include some quotations from my semester in trees that really sum up my feelings about this class: Because of trees, Im going to use fossil fuels for fun. I can put in a thimble what I know about trees. I hate their smug trunks. TL;DR- dont take this class as your science gut. Find something else. An A or an A- is not guaranteed. If youre a STEM person, sure; youll probably enjoy the material. Thats how I feel about trees- thats my story, and Im sticking to it.
If you need a science credit, it's not too bad. I thought it would be more fun, though.

Yes! Craig is an amazing professor. He is amazing at taking science topics which use big, esoteric words and explaining them in lay terms so that everyone can understand. There are some admittedly boring parts of the class (extensively talking about plant hormones and having to memorize where each one is synthesized in a plant and such), but overall, this class puts forth some amazing concepts that really enhance your understanding of the natural world around you. If you get into it, you will really be able to glean a lot from it; if you're not that into it, you can probably still do well, but you should ask yourself why you're taking it at all.
Yes. It is rewarding, low stress, and you actually learn things. You don't just gave to memorize everything.

Yes, if you want to learn about tree biology and the role it has on the environment, then this is a great course if you are looking for a pretty interesting sc credit. If you are looking for a gut, then this is probably not the right course for you. I wouldn't say the course is particularly hard but it does require a good of studying for exams and effort on HW.
Yes
yes; if you need a science credit, go for it. It's only a gut for some people; don't rely on that. Gut has to be defined very loosely in this case. It's really cool stuff though.
Yup! Take the class!
Yes! Take this class if youre into EVST or trees.

Yes, this is a great science course, especially for non-STEM majors! Learned a lot about trees in an accessible, yet still relatively rigorous, way. The TAs are also highly invested in the teaching process and wish to make it an enjoyable experience for all. Love how many connections I can now make between trees, my other academic interests, and daily life in general.
If you have any interest in trees and want to make an effort to find value in the material, then yes do it. At times it takes a lot of effort.

I would recommend this course to another student only if they already had a background in biology / were incredibly interested in learning about trees or horticulture/forestry. Otherwise, I felt as thought it was fairly shallow while also quite difficult (coming from a non-stem field). As a result, I don't think I would recommend the course to anyone outside of those parameters.
Definitely

I would recommend this class to anyone who wants to gain a basic understanding of how trees function and just learn a bunch of cool facts about these organisms that most people take for granted. This class definitely gave me an appreciation for trees that I've never had before, in that I now realize that they are infinitely more complex than I ever expected them to be. This class is a must-take for anyone who is into forestry, the environment, or has an interest in plant biology.
I would definitely recommend this course to other students. This is a great introductory course or for those with little background in ecological studies.
Yes, interesting to learn about trees
Yes! Great way to get a science credit while also learning a lot about trees and how they can help solve climate issues.
I would recommend this course to students who want to learn more about trees, their biology (more so than tree identification), and how they interact with the world around them.
If you're willing to put in the work, yes!

I would recommend this course to someone is looking for a science credit that is NOT a gut. The quizzes and assignments may fool you, but the tests are very difficult and require a lot of preparation to do well. Sit closer to the front so you can hear Craig.
I would definitely recommend this course to another student.
Definitely. There's a lot of support from the TAs and the courseload hits the right balance of challenge and engagement, whilst making sure you're not overwhelmed in the learning process.
Not a gut
Absolutely
Yes, it is a great course for non-science majors.
Of course! This was a great course and I really enjoyed everything about it.
No, the material wasn't intuitive, and it didn't apply to the broader environment, which is why I took the course.
Yes, it is an easy, enjoyable science credit.
100%, a great class to learn more about trees or get involved in the sciences in an approachable way.
No because it was pitched as a class for non science majors but got very scientifically technique in a way that made learning about trees dull and at times confusing

I guess so. I mean it's an okay science credit, and you learn a lot. It's not super difficult information, the testing style was just weird and unpredictable. You have to really be willing to put the work in though. There is a lot of memorization.

Yes! If you are a non-science major looking for a science credit, this is a great option. The class isnt incredibly easy, and it requires a fair amount of evenly-distributed work throughout the semester, but Ive already noticed how the material I learned in this class informs my understanding of the nature around me.
Yes. Especially if the student is not an EVST major, the course gives you an in depth, fresh perspective on the environment and humans' impact. This is literally our future, so learn about it.
not really worth taking as not a stem student. the TFs were horrible.

No, I would not recommend this course unless you are really into trees AND BIOLOGY. If you are thinking of taking the course because it seems like an interesting science class that can be accessible to you as someone who does not like science, do not be fooled: the TAs expect you to know a lot about physics and biology, and some chemistry. Much of the content in this sense, will not seem relevant to you if you are not a scientist, and just care to learn about trees in a broader scale.
N/A
No, the tests are way harder than expected. Even from study guide

I thought the information presented in the class was interesting and accessible. Craig is such a wonderful professor and is so invested in his students as well as the subject matter. If you show up to lecture and take notes, the exams aren't difficult at all.
I would! Not a gut. Not extremely challenging either, but definitely not a gut. A fantastic course.
Definitely! But don't assume it's a gut, you need to pay attention, come to class, take notes, etc. I really loved the subject. I'd say don't take it if you have zero interest in trees.

Yes. This is a great class. Particularly, it is a great science credit for non-science majors. Although, I must say, and I must say loudly, that this is not a gut. I took the class knowing this, but there were murmurs that this class would be very easy. This is not true. It requires a good deal of work and has a workload very much comparable to any other Yale course. I highly recommend that you take it though.
Yes! Very well integrated class that is exciting for a science requirement.
Yes. Gives an interesting real world spin on statistics

I would recommend this course to another student looking for a science credit. I would not recommend this class to a student who is looking to major in a science (aside from maybe the EVST B.A.) because a lot of this information will be a lower-level repeat of things they will come across later. I thought that Craig was a good lecturer and his slides were detailed enough that it is possible to not go to class and still keep up (though sometimes he gives extra credit to people who attend lecture). The TFs are good. I don't think this class is a complete gut - I was taking this class along with some other easy classes and probably ended up studying for the Trees tests the most, but it still wasn't terrible. Just don't expect to do nothing for the class.
not really, no. it might make you dislike looking at trees because you'll remember how necessarily stressful this class can be at times.
Yes! A great science credit that helps you get outside and get to know the School of Forestry.
Yes. It was informative and not too complex for a non-stem person such as myself.

I would recommend this course to other students, but those who are looking for a "gut" class, this may not be the best choice! (Are guts even real here at Yale?) This is a class that you MUST put work in in order to get a good grade (the class average for the first midterm was a C...

YES!! It is a lot of detail, but it is so much fun to learn how plants actually work and understand the relationship and similarities we have with them. the field trips are cool and the TAs are all super cool and helpful! Be prepared for constant quizzes, though.
